summary: A brain tumor is a growth of abnormal cells in the tissues of the brain. They can be benign (non-cancerous) or malignant (cancerous). Primary brain tumors start in the brain, while secondary (metastatic) tumors spread from elsewhere in the body. Symptoms vary based on size, location, and growth rate, and can include headaches, seizures, vision problems, vomiting, mental changes, difficulty with movement or speech, and behavioral changes. Diagnosis typically involves medical examination, imaging (MRI, CT scans), and biopsy. Treatment may include surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, and targeted therapy.
causes: Genetic mutations activating oncogenes or deactivating tumor suppressor genes (e.g., TP53, IDH1, IDH2)
Exposure to ionizing radiation (including CT scan radiation)
Inherited syndromes (e.g., neurofibromatosis, tuberous sclerosis, von Hippel-Lindau Disease, multiple endocrine neoplasia, neurofibromatosis type 2)
risk_factors: Mobile phone radiation (classified as possibly carcinogenic, Group 2B by WHO)
symptoms: Headaches (often in the morning, worse with Valsalva maneuver, awakening from sleep, progressively worsening, atypical features)
Difficulty with writing, drawing, naming, and recognizing
Poor vision or loss of vision
diagnosis: Genetic and chromosomal testing (e.g., for IDH1, IDH2, TP53, ATRX, EGFR, TERT, PTEN mutations, 1p/19q co-deletion)
treatments: Surgery (complete or partial resection, gross total resection, cytoreduction, trans-nasal, trans-sphenoidal approach, craniotomy)

Radiation therapy (external beam radiation therapy, radiosurgery, stereotactic radiosurgery, Gamma knife, Cyberknife, Novalis Tx radiosurgery, whole-brain radiotherapy treatment (WBRT), brachytherapy, proton therapy)
Targeted therapy (e.g., anti-VEGFA antibody like Bevacizumab)
